bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, March 6, 1923

div1.p: Frost discusses Snow's book on cholera. He informs Carter that he will be lecturing in Washington, D.C. next month.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, March 6, 1923
div1.opener:
Bark
Frost &Snow
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. March 6, 1923.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I must apologize as usual for not
having more promptly acknowledged your two letters,
one in regard to the malignant angina reported in the
Anales de Chimalpabin (?) the other in regard to Dr.
Snow's work on cholera. I am very much obliged to you
for the references on diphtheria which Dr. Doull will
follow up as diphtheria is his field rather than mine;
and I am glad that you found Dr. Snow's book so satis-
fying. When I first came across it two or three
years ago I was immediately filled with enthusiasm and
admiration of the reasoning and presentation, and am
glad to find you share the enthusiasm. Someone who has
a gift for writing ought to, I think, bring Snow's work
more to the knowledge of the present generation. I do
not think that he has ever received his full share of
credit from either his contemporaries or his followers.

I find that I shall have to be in Wash-
ington from time to time during April to give some lec-
tures at the Hygienic Laboratory, much to my disgust,
as I am rather nauseated with lectures, but I hope that
I may have some compensation in having an opportunity
to see something of you while there.

With best regards to yourself and Miss
Laura, and hoping that you are both feeling well enough
to enjoy the work which I am sure you are doing,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHF:G
